shortDescription: Graham Number responds to the question - What is the maximum value of the stock that investor should maximally consider. Usually, every value below Graham Number is considered as a good opportunity to buy.
extensiveDescription: Calculated on the basis of Book value and Earning per Share ratios. It is estimator of the maximum price per share, with which paid the company would be still profitable. It is one of many useful ratios. However, on the opposite to other ratios, it shouldn't be compared across the companies, even within the industry. The only comparison that is allowed is with actual share price. Of course, Graham Number may not be the only determinant of investment decision. Combined with types of ratios can be a great addition to overall analysis.
formula: SQRT(22,5 * Earnings per Share * Book Value per Share)
example: Let's assume that The Company 1 has EPS value equal to $10 and Book per Value equal $5. In that case, Graham Number is $33.54. That value is the maximum amount that investor should pay for the share of TC1. Every price share below $33.54 would be profitable and every price above that figure is deemed as not worth consideration.
bulletPointSummary: Determines maximum fair value of stock.
Stock price below Graham Number is considered as undervalued.
Must be considered separately from anothers companies or averages.
Analyze with: Indyvidually, not compared to others

intervalsData.name: Graham Number
intervalsData.summary: Graham Number has no real intervals of values. Each case must be analyzed individually compared with current share price. Maximum profitable Graham Number is a square root of multiplication 22,5 times P/E ratio and 1.5 times P/B ratio. Above that value stock most likely won't be able to bring any profits.
